Abstract: Conference Title: 2025 Conference on Information Communications Technology and Society (ICTAS) Conference Start Date: 2025 July 23 Conference End Date: 2025 July 25 Conference Location: Durban, South Africa To promote a deeper understanding of concepts, higher-order thinking, and long-term knowledge retention, educators in engineering are increasingly adopting alternative assessments, such as authentic assessments. This study presents the adoption and outcomes of an authentic assessment approach replacing the traditional final examination used in a core mathematics course of an undergraduate engineering curriculum. The research aimed to (1) explore the impact of the assessment approach in promoting students’ higher-order thinking skills, and (2) identify learning gains reported by students that demonstrate deep and meaningful learning in the core math course for engineers. A mixed-method approach was used, involving 74 second and third-year engineering students enrolled in the Differential Equations course during the 3 rd semester of the 2023/2024 academic year at Ashesi University. Data collected included post-course surveys, reflections, audio recordings of the final oral assessment pitches, and student performance scores. The results showed that, on average, students showcased growth in understanding and competency of transferring knowledge beyond application word problems to solving real-life problems through the authentic assessment approach. Students also noted that the assessment approach greatly impacted their learning experience, including their motivation to take a deep approach to learning, confidence, sense of relevance, usefulness, and connection of concepts to real-life, personal interests, and future careers. In general, the study indicates that the assessment approach can help students move beyond focusing on grades and passing examinations and instead prepare them to become deep and meaningful thinkers who can confidently approach real-life workplace tasks.

Abstract: Conference Title: 2025 5th International Conference on Computer Science and Blockchain (CCSB) Conference Start Date: 2025 Aug. 1 Conference End Date: 2025 Aug. 3 Conference Location: Shenzhen, China Continual Learning (CL) for large pre-trained models faces the challenge of knowledge forgetting when adapting to new data. While parameter-efficient fine-tuning techniques like LoRA show promise in mitigating catastrophic forgetting, existing methods either indiscriminately accumulate modules or fail to maintain knowledge consistency. We propose Dynamic Routing and Distillation-Aware Fusion for LoRA-based Continual Learning (DRDF-LoRA), a novel framework that introduces a dynamic LoRA selection mechanism to reuse historical knowledge modules in a task-boundary-free manner, and performs elastic LoRA fusion guided by behavioral distillation from earlier stages. We conduct experiments on challenging continual visual question answering (VQA-CL) benchmarks. The results demonstrate that DRDF-LoRA significantly outperforms baseline methods in terms of accuracy, knowledge retention, and parameter efficiency, showcasing its ability to achieve long-term knowledge preservation after fine-tuning large models on complex tasks.

Meta-Learning Curriculum Agent (MLCA): A Hierarchical Framework for Cross-Environment Adaptation in Reinforcement Learning
Author: Xu, Zihan11 Dalian University of Technology, DUT—RU International School of Information Science & Engineering at DUT,Dalian,China
Publication info: Xu, Zihan.
Abstract: Conference Title: 2025 5th International Conference on Computer Science and Blockchain (CCSB) Conference Start Date: 2025 Aug. 1 Conference End Date: 2025 Aug. 3 Conference Location: Shenzhen, China We propose the Meta-Learning Curriculum Agent (MLCA), a hierarchical framework designed to address the challenge of cross-environment adaptation in reinforcement learning (RL). Traditional transfer learning methods often rely on static pre-training or manually designed curricula, which struggle to generalize across diverse and dynamic environments. The MLCA merges meta-learning with curriculum learning via a three-part structure: a Meta-Learner that deduces task relevance from environmental features, alongside a dynamically adjusting Curriculum Generator for task difficulty, and a Policy Adaptation Module supporting swift fine-tuning. The Meta-Learner employs a Transformer-based encoder to capture temporal and taskspecific patterns, while the Curriculum Generator optimizes task selection by balancing performance improvement and knowledge retention. Additionally, the Policy Adaptation Module employs gradient-based meta-learning to adjust policies effectively with limited retraining. The framework functions by means of asynchronous data pipelines and establishes a closed-loop system in which curriculum modifications are directed by real-time agent performance. MLCA differs from prior methods by employing a dual-loop optimization that simultaneously refines task ordering and policy adjustment, avoiding dependence on predetermined schedules. Initial experiments on algorithmically constructed benchmarks show better generalization than traditional approaches. The MLCA's ability to autonomously generate adaptive curricula makes it particularly suitable for applications requiring robust RL agents in non-stationary environments, such as robotics and autonomous systems.

Publication info: Chen, Wen; Chen, Yingji.
Abstract: In the evolving landscape of digital cultural heritage, the integration of advanced computational models into immersive virtual environments has become essential for enriching user engagement and fostering more meaningful interpretative experiences. As digital heritage platforms increasingly adopt interactive technologies, there is a growing need to move beyond static presentations and introduce intelligent, responsive systems that adapt to individual users’ interests and behaviors. Traditional virtual museum systems often suffer from rigid content structures, limited adaptability, and a lack of personalized storytelling, all of which constrain user immersion and diminish the potential for impactful learning experiences. To overcome these challenges, our approach integrates semantic-topological modeling with adaptive interaction mechanisms, forming a dynamic and personalized digital museum experience. The proposed framework features a hybrid computational architecture that unites symbolic knowledge representations with algorithmic spatial layout generation. This integration enables the creation of flexible narrative trajectories that are contextually relevant and customized according to each user’s cognitive and behavioral profile. Furthermore, the system incorporates reinforcement-driven semantic planning to interpret and respond to user interactions in real time, ensuring a continuously evolving and coherent interpretative journey. Experimental results reveal substantial improvements in user satisfaction, engagement levels, and knowledge retention when compared to traditional virtual museum platforms. These outcomes highlight the scalability and transformative potential of the model, reinforcing its capacity to enhance accessibility, personalization, and educational value across diverse digital heritage applications.

Author: Tian Zonggui    ; Zhang, Du
Publication info: Tian Zonggui; Zhang, Du.
Abstract: Humans have the ability to incrementally learn, accumulate, update, and apply knowledge from dynamic environments. This capability, known as continual learning or lifelong learning, is also a long-term goal in the development of artificial intelligence. However, neural network-based continual learning suffers from catastrophic forgetting: the acquisition of new knowledge typically disrupts previously learned knowledge, leading to partial forgetting and a decline in the model’s overall performance. Most current continual learning methods can only mitigate catastrophic forgetting and fail to incrementally improve the overall performance. In this work, we aim to incrementally improve performance within sample incremental context by utilizing inter-stage edges as a pathway for explicit knowledge transfer in continual graph learning. Building on this pathway, we propose a knowledge-augmented replay method by leveraging evolving subgraphs of important nodes. This method enhances the distinction between patterns associated with different node classes and consolidates previously learned knowledge. Experiments on phishing detection in Ethereum transaction networks validate the effectiveness of the proposed method, demonstrating effective knowledge retention and augmentation while overcoming catastrophic forgetting and incrementally improving performance. The results also reveal the relationship between average accuracy and average forgetting. Lastly, we identify the key factor to incremental performance improvement, which lays a foundation for convergence of continual graph learning.

Abstract: Conference Title: 2025 IEEE 8th International Conference on Electrical, Control and Computer Engineering (InECCE) Conference Start Date: 2025 Aug. 27 Conference End Date: 2025 Aug. 28 Conference Location: Kuantan, Malaysia Study schedule management and memorization of huge information is the work of a student and a professional. The traditional way of learning is not personalized and flexible which leads to bad study habits and low retention of knowledge. This project will be developing PrepPal AI which is a cloudbased study planner which uses artificial intelligence to create personalized study schedules, topic roadmap and ai-driven flashcards. System is developed using React for frontend, Node.js for backend API development and MongoDB Atlas for database management. Falcon-7B-Instruct is used to create flashcards based on the user's input content such as text, images, pdf files etc. Spaced repetition is used to get the maximum revision cycle of topics. Intelligent reminder is used to maximize learning efficiency. The system is able to effectively create customized study plans based on user's preference. Plans made by the system are also more suitable to the user's needs. It improves users' time management and helps them to learn in an organized way. AI-generated flashcards help improve knowledge retention. The system's track progress feature helps users to keep track of their studies. Automated reminder and personalized resource recommendation also helps to maximize learning efficiency. PrepPal AI provides a smart, flexible and organized way of learning which makes it easy for students and professionals to achieve their study goals. Features such as multilingual, may be added in the future. Other AI-driven quizzes might also be added. More integrations with learning platforms may also be added.

Abstract: Conference Title: 2025 IEEE Integrated STEM Education Conference (ISEC) Conference Start Date: 2025 March 15 Conference End Date: 2025 March 15 Conference Location: Princeton, NJ, USA This paper introduces the "Flipped Role" methodology applied in the undergraduate course "Digital Communication", part of the degree program in "Media, Communication, and Society". This approach redefines traditional roles in education, assigning students the responsibility of acting as educators. They develop teaching materials, quizzes, and lessons, leveraging Generative Artificial Intelligence (GenAI) as a supportive and interactive tool. The instructor’s role shifts to that of a facilitator, guiding students through a structured, phase-based process and integrating AI tools to enhance the collaborative and engaging learning experience. The primary objective of this methodology is to explore how role reversal and active engagement with AI can support deeper comprehension, improved knowledge retention, and greater awareness of GenAI’s appropriate and responsible use. By placing students at the center of content creation and decision-making, the "Flipped Role" aims to foster a collaborative and reflective educational environment while demonstrating the practical potential of AI-enhanced active learning.

Author: Miller-Wilkerson, Celeste
Publication info: Miller-Wilkerson, Celeste.
Abstract: Hypertensive disorders of pregnancy (HDP) are a leading cause of maternal morbidity and mortality in the United States, disproportionately impacting Black birthing individuals due to systemic racism, healthcare inequities, and insufficient postpartum education. Despite clinical guidelines, HDP warning signs often go unrecognized, delaying timely intervention. This quality improvement project primarily aimed to evaluate the impact of evidence-based education on HDP symptom recognition and the time to seek care. Secondary aims were to (1) assess the effect of racially congruent video education on patient satisfaction and (2) evaluate the impact of video-based education on HDP knowledge retention. Conducted at a Gulf Coast perinatal clinic serving a predominantly non-Hispanic Black population, the intervention included a culturally representative flyer and a racially congruent educational video, both introduced at the initial postpartum visit. Eligible participants were postpartum individuals up to six weeks, English-speaking, aged 18 or older, and with access to a mobile device. The project used pre- and post-design, comparing data collected three months before and three months after the practice change. HDP knowledge was assessed using a multiple-choice survey; satisfaction was measured using a Likert-scale tool. Unexpected permanent clinic closure one week after project launch significantly disrupted data collection. Three pre-intervention knowledge surveys and two satisfaction surveys were completed. Knowledge scores averaged 86.7% (range: 66–100%), showing varied baseline awareness. Satisfaction data showed a positive shift in patient trust and engagement. Lessons learned included the need for early, hands-on training with clinic staff and the primary stakeholder on digital tools, clearer communication throughout the team, and secure infrastructure to support implementation. Additionally, future projects should obtain funding to support higher-quality educational video production. Establishing strong stakeholder engagement and identifying on-site practice champions are critical to maintaining fidelity, troubleshooting barriers, and supporting sustainability. Most critically, addressing racial disparities in maternal health requires embedding equity from the outset; through community co-design, systemic alignment, and long-term commitment to culturally responsive care. With adequate resources and collaborative leadership, racially congruent education can be fully integrated into postpartum workflows to improve patient trust, health literacy, and timely care-seeking, ultimately advancing equity in perinatal outcomes.

Abstract: Conference Title: 2025 International Seminar on Intelligent Technology and Its Applications (ISITIA) Conference Start Date: 2025 July 23 Conference End Date: 2025 July 25 Conference Location: Surabaya, Indonesia Virtual Reality (VR) has emerged as a transformative technology in agricultural education, offering innovative solutions for practical training and experiential learning. This systematic literature review, conducted using the PRISMA framework, examines the implementation, effectiveness, and challenges of VR in farming education. The analysis reveals that VR technology significantly enhances student engagement and knowledge retention through immersive simulations, particularly beneficial in agricultural training where hands-on experience is traditionally limited by physical resources. While VR demonstrates considerable potential in democratizing agricultural education by providing urban students access to farming simulations, the study identifies key challenges including technological limitations and high equipment costs. The findings suggest that despite these obstacles, VR's capacity to bridge the gap between theoretical knowledge and practical application makes it a valuable tool for developing future agricultural expertise. This review highlights VR's role in preparing learners for emerging challenges in food security and modern farming practices, while emphasizing the need for structured educational frameworks to guide its implementation in agricultural curricula.

Abstract: Conference Title: 2025 International Conference on Communication, Computing, Networking, and Control in Cyber-Physical Systems (CCNCPS) Conference Start Date: 2025 June 10 Conference End Date: 2025 June 12 Conference Location: Dubai, United Arab Emirates This paper presents the design, development, and evaluation of an intelligent gamified reviewer system aimed at fostering personalized and active learning within cyber-physical education environments. The system features a modular, web-based architecture and incorporates gamification elements—such as points, badges, progression levels, and real-time leaderboards—within a responsive interface accessible via desktop and mobile devices. The core objective is to enhance student engagement, monitor academic performance, and reinforce knowledge retention beyond traditional classroom settings. Employing the Rapid Application Development (RAD) methodology, the system underwent iterative prototyping and stakeholder-driven refinement. A comprehensive dual-model evaluation was conducted. The ISO/IEC 25010 software quality model assessed functionality, performance efficiency, compatibility, usability, reliability, and security, while McCall’s Software Quality Model addressed maintainability, portability, and code-level attributes. Results showed high overall ratings, particularly in usability (M = 4.66), maintainability (4.82), and portability (4.73), affirming both pedagogical and technical efficacy. Although tested in a specific academic context, the architecture and methodology are transferable to broader educational and training environments. This work contributes to the field of intelligent cyber-physical systems by demonstrating how gamified tools can deliver scalable, quality- driven educational solutions.

Education Enhanced: Impact of Immersive Technologies on Teaching and Learning Outcomes
Author: Izouaouen, Zakaria1; Kharmoum, Nassim1; Ziti, Soumia11 Mohammed V University in Rabat,IPSS, Intelligent Processing And Security of Systems, Faculty of Sciences,Rabat,Morocco

Abstract: Conference Title: 2025 International Conference on Circuit, Systems and Communication (ICCSC) Conference Start Date: 2025 June 19 Conference End Date: 2025 June 20 Conference Location: Fez, Morocco Immersive technologies, including virtual reality, augmented reality, and mixed reality, commonly known as VR, AR and MR, are transforming the educational landscape by providing engaging, interactive, and highly effective learning environments. This paper explores the impact of immersive technologies on teaching methodologies and learning outcomes, focusing on student engagement, knowledge retention, critical thinking, and accessibility. A mixed-methods approach, incorporating a systematic literature review, quantitative analysis of case studies, and qualitative interviews with educators and students, is employed to demonstrate the transformative potential of immersive technologies in education. The findings reveal that immersive learning environments significantly enhance student engagement, knowledge retention, critical thinking skills, and accessibility, offering a more engaging, effective, and inclusive approach to teaching and learning. The implications of these findings for the future of education are discussed, and actionable recommendations are provided for educators, policymakers, and researchers to leverage immersive technologies effectively in teaching and learning. The adoption of these innovations has the potential to create a more engaging, equitable, and impactful educational experience for all learners.

Abstract: Conference Title: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Decentralized Applications and Infrastructures (DAPPS) Conference Start Date: 2025 July 21 Conference End Date: 2025 July 24 Conference Location: Tucson, AZ, USA Academic and research environments struggle with unrecognized contributions, inefficient incentive structures, and knowledge loss due to frequent staff turnover. This paper proposes a decentralized reward framework integrating verifiable credentials and programmable money to enhance trust, transparency, and automation in organizational incentives. By linking digital credentials to programmable rewards, contributions can be verified, acknowledged, and compensated based on predefined, rule-based criteria. This eliminates the need for centralized oversight, ensuring transparent and tamper-proof reward distribution while reducing administrative overhead. We explore the system’s design, discuss its potential impact on research organizations, and analyze both its benefits and challenges, including usability, adoption barriers, and security considerations. Furthermore, we examine extensions such as group-based credential issuance and decentralized validation to improve fairness and adaptability. This work offers a novel perspective on leveraging decentralized technologies for incentives, setting the stage for further investigation into its practical feasibility and adoption.

Adapt but Do Not Forget: Towards Enhancing Drift Handling in 6G Networks
Author: Ameur, Mazene1; Brik, Bouziane2; Ksentini, Adlen11 EURECOM,Communication Systems Department,Sophia Antipolis,France2 University of Sharjah,Computer Science Department,Sharjah,UAE
Publication info: Ameur, Mazene; Brik, Bouziane; Ksentini, Adlen.
Abstract: Conference Title: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Machine Learning for Communication and Networking (ICMLCN) Conference Start Date: 2025 May 26 Conference End Date: 2025 May 29 Conference Location: Barcelona, Spain The advent of 6G represents a paradigm shift where Artificial Intelligence and Machine Learning AI/ML becoming the pulsating heart of network innovation. However, these AI/ML models face a significant challenge known as Model Drift, caused by changes in data distributions and feature relationships over time, leading to degraded performance. While numerous drift adaptation strategies have been explored including model retraining, incremental learning, and ensemble approaches, they often neglect the critical issue of "Catastrophic Forgetting" (CF). The latter refers to the phenomenon where neural networks, upon learning new information (post-drift), lose the ability to retain previously learned knowledge (pre-drift). This challenge is particularly pronounced in the time-series forecasting tasks inherent to telecommunications networks, where sequential data dependencies amplify the forgetting issue. To address this limitation, we propose a novel LSTM-EWC model that synergistically combines the time-series processing strengths of Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) networks with the CF mitigation capabilities of Elastic Weight Consolidation (EWC). The proposed framework empowers LSTM models to retain essential pre-drift knowledge, while effectively adapting to post-drift changes, enabling robust and continuous learning in dynamic environments. Experimental evaluations on a real-world telecommunications dataset highlight the efficacy of our approach, demonstrating up to 51% improvement in knowledge retention over state-of-the-art CF baseline methods.

Abstract: Conference Title: 2025 MIPRO 48th ICT and Electronics Convention Conference Start Date: 2025 June 2 Conference End Date: 2025 June 6 Conference Location: Opatija, Croatia This paper presents an innovative and novel multimodal AI tutoring framework in the effort to increase the effectiveness of personalized engineering learning experiences. Filling the gaps in adaptive tutoring systems and considering people's emotional engagement, the framework combines the cognitive load theory, indicators of emotional intelligence, and adaptive learning algorithms to develop an overarching, context-specific instructional landscape. The study makes use of a mixed-methods design, using machine learning driven tutoring interfaces, state of the art learning analytics, and sentiment analysis on a long-term study with 68 engineering students. Incorporating powerful affective computing techniques and intelligent intervention methods, this study presents an encompassing approach that can tune the scaffolding support to learners' abilities and adjust to everchanging competencies of learners while being proactive about detecting the indicators of cognitive overload. The uniqueness aspect of this research lies in its synergistic combination of various data streams (multimodal) - text, visual, and biometric data - combined with dynamic AI-based recommendation model, which maximizes personalized feedback loops. Theoretically, the study expands the insights into how the cognitive load and the emotional dynamics form learning outcomes. Practically, it provides a scalable, flexible approach to the integration of multimodal AI tutors in various educational environments. This work helps to bridge the gap between the cognitive science principles and educational technology solutions and offers new findings regarding designing effective, user-centric intelligent tutoring systems that increase knowledge retention, create motivation, and increase the engineering education outcomes.

Abstract: Conference Title: 2025 11th International Conference on Education and Training Technologies (ICETT) Conference Start Date: 2025 May 23 Conference End Date: 2025 May 25 Conference Location: Macao, China The integration of podcasting into higher education has revolutionized learning methodologies, offering a flexible, engaging, and learner-centered approach. This study examines the impact of podcasting attributes on learning outcomes among communication students in Calamba City, Laguna, with engagement and perceived usefulness as mediating variables. Grounded in the Technology Acceptance Model (TAM) and Engagement Theory, this research employs Structural Equation Modeling (SEM) to analyze data collected from undergraduate communication students. The findings reveal that well-structured and interactive podcasts significantly enhance student engagement and perceived usefulness, positively mediating the relationship between podcasting attributes and learning outcomes. Results indicate that podcasting fosters cognitive engagement, facilitates knowledge retention, and improves academic performance, serving as an effective pedagogical tool. The study underscores the need for educators to optimize podcast content through high-quality production, structured delivery, and interactive elements to maximize its educational benefits. Moreover, it highlights the importance of accessibility and inclusivity in podcast-based learning to accommodate diverse learners. The research provides critical insights for educational institutions leveraging digital tools for enhanced student engagement and academic success. Future studies should explore the long-term cognitive effects of podcast-based learning and its adaptability across different disciplines. This study contributes to the evolving discourse on digital pedagogy, reinforcing podcasting as a strategic medium for modern education

Abstract: Conference Title: 2025 IEEE 53rd Photovoltaic Specialists Conference (PVSC) Conference Start Date: 2025 June 8 Conference End Date: 2025 June 13 Conference Location: Montreal, QC, Canada This paper introduces a gamified learning framework for photovoltaics (PV) education, developed through the EU-funded TRANSIT and PROMISE projects. Recognizing the pedagogical challenges of teaching complex PV principles and practical operation and maintenance (O&M) skills, the framework leverages interactive, game-based methodologies. The TRANSIT Online Training Platform utilizes scenario-based simulations and multiplayer environments for foundational concepts and PV system design. Complementing this, the PROMISE project incorporates two custom-designed board games to explore O&M complexities: a "tycoon"-style game for introductory concepts and a facilitator-guided game for in-depth discussions. Preliminary results indicate increased learner engagement, knowledge retention, and enhanced problem-solving skills, bridging the gap between theoretical knowledge and real-world application in PV systems. Future efforts will focus on scaling the platform and integrating advanced technologies.

Practical Application and Industry Relev: The Role of Off-Campus Training in Student Skill Development
Author: Jia, Rusheng
Publication info: Jia, Rusheng.
Abstract: An off-campus practical course is one in which students receive practical training in a vocational workplace outside of their educational institution. These courses focus on practical skills rather than academic knowledge and are essential for students to gain real-world experience and develop skills needed in the modern workforce. The research objective is to explore the continuous development of off-campus practical courses using the Outcome-Based Education (OBE) framework. The study used both qualitative and quantitative research methods, with 900 structured questionnaires distributed and 847 valid responses collected from students and teachers. The quantitative data were analyzed using SPSS software, and the qualitative data were analyzed using NVivo software. The findings highlight that off-campus practical courses improve students' problem-solving skills, practical application abilities, industry-relevant performance, and engagement compared to traditional classroom-based education. Theoretically, this study contributes to the growing body of research on OBE by demonstrating how off-campus practical courses, when aligned with OBE principles, can better equip students with the skills required by modern industries. The study enriches the OBE framework by providing evidence of how it enhances not only technical knowledge retention but also fosters critical competencies such as problem-solving, industry-specific performance, and engagement. Practically, the study provides insights for educators and industry stakeholders to design off-campus programs that align with both academic and vocational outcomes. The novelty of this study lies in its exploration of how off-campus practical courses can be continuously improved to better prepare students for the challenges of the contemporary workplace.

Author: Shih-Yu, Li    ; Chun-Yu, Ho; Wu, Shih-Ping
Publication info: Shih-Yu, Li; Chun-Yu, Ho; Wu, Shih-Ping.
Abstract: This study originates from the observation during teaching and student interactions that students in industry-academic cooperative programs have very limited time to dedicate to coursework. The target group for this research consists of third-year students in the Mechanical Engineering industry-academia collaborative training program, and sessions are conducted in the shared computer lab, Room 312. All 40 students were informed of the study details and signed consent forms. This research was initiated based on observations from teaching sessions and internship evaluations, which revealed that these students face challenges such as heavy workloads, condensed class schedules, and limited familiarity with programming. With limited classroom time, designing content that captures students' attention and enhances learning efficiency is a primary objective of this study. This research introduces a topic-based teaching approach, which was pilot-tested in the 2021 academic year and fully implemented in the 2022 academic year. The topic-based approach comprises three stages: topic explanation and programming implementation, problem-based exercises with peer learning, and results presentation with in-depth discussion. After completing each topic, both qualitative and quantitative questionnaires are administered to facilitate rapid instructional feedback, thereby scientifically refining the teaching and learning process. The study findings show high effectiveness in quantitative metrics, with student evaluations consistently above 4 out of 5 and a gradual increase in satisfaction with the teaching team as topic difficulty rose (from 4.48 to 4.70). In qualitative feedback, students expressed strong agreement that the topic-based approach enhanced their understanding of programming applications and techniques, peer interactions deepened knowledge retention, and team presentations fostered greater engagement. Course evaluation scores improved from 4.03 to 4.49, and final grades increased significantly from 70.23 to 87.26 (with a 12.7% improvement in teaching effectiveness and a 24.2% increase in overall semester grades.). These results indicate that, compared to conventional teaching methods, the topic-based approach effectively ignites students' enthusiasm for learning and improves learning outcomes.

Author: Basgül, Melek    ; Bayram Costu
Publication info: Basgül, Melek; Bayram Costu.
Abstract: Education 4.0 represents a visionary approach to the future of education, aiming to enhance teaching and learning through advanced technologies. The aim of this research is to determine student attitudes toward the use of Education 4.0 tools in the 7th-grade Science course Electrical Circuits unit. To achieve this, an attitude test was developed to evaluate the integration of Education 4.0 tools into the Science curriculum, and student attitudes were assessed using this test. A "quasi-experimental design with pre-test and post-test control group," one of the quantitative research methods, was used in the study. The research involved 41 seventh-grade students from one public secondary schools in Turkey, with 21 students in the experimental group and 20 in the control group. The "Attitude Scale toward the Use of Education 4.0 Tools in Science Teaching," developed by the researchers, was used as the data collection instrument. The experimental phase lasted four weeks (16 lesson hours), during which the experimental group engaged in activities involving Education 4.0 tools, while the control group followed the curriculum-prescribed activities. The t-test results of the collected data revealed a statistically significant difference between the post-test scores of the experimental and control groups, with the experimental group showing more favorable outcomes. The research findings reveal that students exhibit a positive attitude toward the use of Education 4.0 tools in science education. These results suggest that the integration of Education 4.0 into science education enhances students' understanding of abstract electrical concepts such as electric current, potential difference, resistance, and Ohm's Law, improves knowledge retention, and transforms the learning process into an interactive and discovery-oriented experience. Furthermore, Education 4.0 tools have contributed to the improvement of learning outcomes by promoting student engagement and make learning processes more efficient by improving students' ability to use technology effectively.

Author: Faraji, Aazaade1; Pombo, Nuno21 Universidade da Beira Interior,Covilhã,Portugal2 Instituto de Telecomunicações, Universidade da Beira Interior,Covilhã,Portugal

Abstract: Conference Title: 2025 IEEE 49th Annual Computers, Software, and Applications Conference (COMPSAC) Conference Start Date: 2025 July 8 Conference End Date: 2025 July 11 Conference Location: Toronto, ON, Canada This study examines the integration of futuristic thinking methodologies into X-Ops education, encompassing topics such as DevOps, AIOps, DataOps, and DevSecOps. Traditional teaching methods often fail to bridge the gap between theoretical knowledge and practical application, leaving students unprepared for the evolving demands of the industry. To address these challenges, this research introduced speculative and experiential learning strategies, including science fiction prototyping, movie analysis, flash fiction storytelling, and innovation labs. These activities aimed to enhance engagement, knowledge retention, critical thinking, and collaborative skills by immersing students in creative and hands-on problem-solving scenarios.The findings demonstrate that futuristic thinking methodologies significantly improve students’ understanding of X-Ops concepts, fostering creativity and innovation while promoting collaboration and ethical reasoning. Quantitative data revealed marked improvements in familiarity with X-Ops principles and problem-solving confidence, while qualitative reflections highlighted the value of group-based activities in contextualizing abstract theories. Despite limitations such as sample size and short-term observation, the study underscores the transformative potential of active and future-oriented pedagogies. By bridging the gap between theory and practice, these approaches prepare students to thrive in the dynamic and evolving landscape of modern technological systems.

Abstract: Conference Title: 2025 6th International Conference of the Portuguese Society for Engineering Education (CISPEE) Conference Start Date: 2025 July 16 Conference End Date: 2025 July 18 Conference Location: Setúbal, Portugal The FIT4FUTURE project is an innovative initiative aimed at empowering STEM educators by enhancing their strategic long-term planning skills through the integration of Long-Term Future Scenarios (LTFS) into higher education curricula. This study presents the results of the piloting phase of the FIT4FUTURE project, which was conducted across four European countries: Denmark, Germany, Portugal, and Türkiye. The pilot involved extensive collaboration with higher education institutions in these regions, where the training programme and platform were tested in real-world educational settings. Educators were provided with access to LTFS tools, methodologies, and creative approaches such as science fiction prototyping, flash fiction writing, and trend analysis, all aimed at promoting forward-thinking in STEM education. The findings from the pilot reveal high levels of satisfaction among participants, with educators reporting significant improvements in their ability to incorporate long-term forecasting into their teaching practices. The programme was also found to have a positive impact on student engagement, with educators observing increased motivation, attention, and knowledge retention among their students. Additionally, the flexibility of the training programme allowed educators to tailor the content to their specific educational contexts, further enhancing its relevance and applicability.

Author: Anbazhagan, Aravindhan1; Baskarasethupathi, R21 Educerelator (OPC) Pvt Ltd2 Consultant

Abstract: Conference Title: 2025 IEEE International Professional Communication Conference (ProComm) Conference Start Date: 2025 July 20 Conference End Date: 2025 July 23 Conference Location: Sønderborg, Denmark Students across various academic disciplines struggle with memory retention, particularly during high-stakes examinations. Traditional memorization techniques, such as rote learning and mnemonics, often fail to support long-term knowledge retention. This paper introduces AI-driven memory scripts, an innovative approach that structures learning materials using mind mapping, storytelling, humor, music, and visual techniques to enhance recall. Rather than replacing human-led instructional methods, AI acts as a technical communication aid, applying natural language processing (NLP) and machine learning to generate personalized, structured memory scripts aligned with individual learning styles. These scripts facilitate adaptive exam preparation and support clearer content delivery, demonstrating potential applications in science, mathematics, and language learning. While this approach remains conceptual, it provides a compelling framework for scalable, learner-centered educational design.

Abstract: Conference Title: 2025 IEEE International Conference on AI and Data Analytics (ICAD) Conference Start Date: 2025 June 24 Conference End Date: 2025 June 24 Conference Location: Medford, MA, USA The integration of Augmented Reality (AR) and Artificial Intelligence (AI) in education has emerged as a transformative approach to enhancing student engagement and personalized learning experiences. AI has accelerated the growth of AR dramatically. This paper explores the synergistic potential of AR and AI technologies, highlighting their capacity to create an education environment that cater to diverse requirements of education. It is found that $A R$ applications significantly boost student motivation and knowledge retention, while AI-driven adaptive learning systems boost up academic performance by tailoring educational content to specific learners. However, there are some challenges related to data privacy, security, and equitable access to technology remain critical concerns that must be addressed to fully realize the benefits of these innovations. By examining existing literature and presenting a comprehensive framework for implementation, this study underscores the importance of ethical considerations and the evolving role of educators in AI-augmented environments. The findings emphasize the importance of ongoing research to develop effective strategies that bridge technology and pedagogy, resulting in secure, personalized, and engaging educational experiences.

Abstract: Conference Title: 2025 International Conference on Smart Applications, Communications and Networking (SmartNets) Conference Start Date: 2025 July 22 Conference End Date: 2025 July 24 Conference Location: Istanbul, Turkiye The pressing global imperative to transition to renewable energy sources highlights the critical need for innovative educational strategies to elevate public awareness and comprehension of sustainable energy solutions. Virtual reality (VR) has emerged as a transformative tool in renewable energy education, offering immersive experiences that bridge theoretical knowledge with practical understanding. This literature review synthesizes existing research on VR's applications, evaluating its effectiveness in enhancing engagement, improving knowledge retention, and fostering proenvironmental behavioral change. The study highlights VR's contribution to bridging knowledge-action gaps in sustainability education, expanding the existing literature. While VR offers strong potential, challenges like high development costs, accessibility barriers, and technological limitations persist. Emerging issues such as privacy concerns and equitable access are also acknowledged. Proposed strategies include collaborative content development, cost-effective platforms, and targeted outreach. Future research should explore the longterm sustainability of VR-induced behavioral shifts and scalable applications in diverse contexts. Aligning with the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), VR stands out as a promising tool to promote informed decision-making and accelerate the shift to clean energy systems.

Abstract: The diagnosis and treatment of arthropathic orthopaedic conditions are inherently linked to anatomical structures, necessitating strong spatial visualization abilities in students. Providing intuitively accessible methods for students to master specialized knowledge presents a formidable challenge for educators. This study aims to evaluate the pedagogical value of integrating 3D-printed model with mixed reality (MR) technology in clinical orthopaedic surgery education. Objective The diagnosis and treatment of arthropathic orthopaedic conditions are inherently linked to anatomical structures, necessitating strong spatial visualization abilities in students. Providing intuitively accessible methods for students to master specialized knowledge presents a formidable challenge for educators. This study aims to evaluate the pedagogical value of integrating 3D-printed model with mixed reality (MR) technology in clinical orthopaedic surgery education.Thirty-six senior clinical medical undergraduates were randomized into two groups. The experimental group underwent training using the combined 3D- printed model and mixed reality (MR) technology, while the control group received traditional instruction. Learning outcomes were evaluated through standardized Objective Structured Clinical Examination (OSCE) assessments and questionnaires. Correlation analysis was conducted between total OSCE scores and questionnaire scores. Methods Thirty-six senior clinical medical undergraduates were randomized into two groups. The experimental group underwent training using the combined 3D- printed model and mixed reality (MR) technology, while the control group received traditional instruction. Learning outcomes were evaluated through standardized Objective Structured Clinical Examination (OSCE) assessments and questionnaires. Correlation analysis was conducted between total OSCE scores and questionnaire scores.The experimental group achieved significantly higher OSCE scores compared to the control group ( p    0.8, p    0.8, p < 0.001). The strongest correlation was observed between learning efficiency and OSCE total scores (r = 0.918).Integrating 3D-printed model and MR technology into orthopedic joint surgery clinical teaching significantly boosts student performance, learning efficiency, and overall teaching quality, demonstrating strong potential for wider application. Conclusion Integrating 3D-printed model and MR technology into orthopedic joint surgery clinical teaching significantly boosts student performance, learning efficiency, and overall teaching quality, demonstrating strong potential for wider application.

Abstract: Conference Title: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Engineering, Technology, and Innovation (ICE/ITMC) Conference Start Date: 2025 June 16 Conference End Date: 2025 June 19 Conference Location: Valencia, Spain “Room-of-horrors” is a low-fidelity simulation that places deliberate hazards or mistakes in a simulated clinical setting to develop error-detection skills and situational awareness. Extended Reality technologies, including Virtual Reality and Augmented Reality, offer promising alternatives for delivering room-of-horrors simulations. By allowing repeated, autonomous, and safe practice, these technologies reduce the need to repurpose real clinical spaces and can provide immersive learning experiences. However, the literature has not yet systematically identified optimal extended reality design for effective autonomous room-of-horrors simulations training. This article reviews relevant studies and presents a design framework focusing on non-technical skills, patient safety, and long-term knowledge retention. By integrating insights from serious game-based learning, immersive technology, and clinical education, this framework aims to guide future development of XR-based room-of-horror simulations for safer healthcare practices.

Abstract: Conference Title: 2025 IEEE/CVF Conference on Computer Vision and Pattern Recognition (CVPR) Conference Start Date: 2025 June 10 Conference End Date: 2025 June 17 Conference Location: Nashville, TN, USA Pre-trained Vision-Language Models (VLMs) require Continual Learning (CL) to efficiently update their knowledge and adapt to various downstream tasks without retraining from scratch. However, for VLMs, in addition to the loss of knowledge previously learned from downstream tasks, pre-training knowledge is also corrupted during continual fine-tuning. This issue is exacerbated by the unavailability of original pre-training data, leaving VLM’s generalization ability degrading. In this paper, we propose GIFT, a novel continual fine-tuning approach that utilizes synthetic data to overcome catastrophic forgetting in VLMs. Taking advantage of recent advances in text-to-image synthesis, we employ a pre-trained diffusion model to recreate both pre-training and learned downstream task data. In this way, the VLM can revisit previous knowledge through distillation on matching diffusion-generated images and corresponding text prompts. Leveraging the broad distribution and high alignment between synthetic image-text pairs in VLM’s feature space, we propose a contrastive distillation loss along with an image-text alignment constraint. To further combat in-distribution overfitting and enhance distillation performance with limited amount of generated data, we incorporate adaptive weight consolidation, utilizing Fisher information from these synthetic image-text pairs and achieving a better stability-plasticity balance. Extensive experiments demonstrate that our method consistently outperforms previous state-of-the-art approaches across various settings.

ESC: Erasing Space Concept for Knowledge Deletion
Author: Tae-Young, Lee1; Park, Sundong2; Jeon, Minwoo2; Hwang, Hyoseok2; Park, Gyeong-Moon11 Korea University,Seoul,Republic of Korea2 Kyung Hee University,Yongin,Republic of Korea
Publication info: Tae-Young, Lee; Park, Sundong; Jeon, Minwoo; Hwang, Hyoseok; Park, Gyeong-Moon.
Abstract: Conference Title: 2025 IEEE/CVF Conference on Computer Vision and Pattern Recognition (CVPR) Conference Start Date: 2025 June 10 Conference End Date: 2025 June 17 Conference Location: Nashville, TN, USA As concerns regarding privacy in deep learning continue to grow, individuals are increasingly apprehensive about the potential exploitation of their personal knowledge in trained models. Despite several research efforts to address this, they often fail to consider the real-world demand from users for complete knowledge erasure. Furthermore, our investigation reveals that existing methods have a risk of leaking personal knowledge through embedding features. To address these issues, we introduce a novel concept of Knowledge Deletion (KD), an advanced task that considers both concerns, and provides an appropriate metric, named Knowledge Retention score (KR), for assessing knowledge retention in feature space. To achieve this, we propose a novel training-free erasing approach named Erasing Space Concept (ESC), which restricts the important subspace for the forgetting knowledge by eliminating the relevant activations in the feature. In addition, we suggest ESC with Training (ESC-T), which uses a learnable mask to better balance the trade-off between forgetting and preserving knowledge in KD. Our extensive experiments on various datasets and models demonstrate that our proposed methods achieve the fastest and state-of-the-art performance. Notably, our methods are applicable to diverse forgetting scenarios, such as facial domain setting, demonstrating the generalizability of our methods. The code is available at https://github.com/KU-VGI/ESC.

Author: Bautista-Gomez, Martha Milena    ; Zuluaga Gutierrez, Laura Sofia
Publication info: Bautista-Gomez, Martha Milena; Zuluaga Gutierrez, Laura Sofia.
Abstract: Background: Infectious diseases disproportionately affect rural and ethnic communities in Colombia, where structural inequalities such as limited access to health care, poor sanitation, and scarce health education worsen their effects. Education is essential for preventing and controlling infectious diseases, fostering awareness of healthy behaviors, and empowering communities with the knowledge and skills to manage their health. Participatory and co-design methods strengthen educational programs by ensuring cultural relevance, enhancing knowledge retention, and promoting sustainable community interventions. Objective: This study aims to describe the co-design process and evaluate the capacity building of an education program for the prevention and control of infectious diseases using participatory audiovisual methods culturally adapted to ethnic communities and rural contexts in Colombia. Methods: A qualitative case study approach was used. 15 community leaders contributed to the program’s design, implementation, and evaluation. Nominal groups and a participatory social diagnosis identified key topics, while theoretical-practical sessions with visual methods guided the cocreation of workshops and audiovisual materials. Evaluation combined qualitative analysis of participants’ perceptions and quantitative assessment of knowledge acquisition. Qualitative data were coded through content analysis, while multiple-choice questionnaires (initial and final) categorized knowledge acquisition into 3 levels (low, medium, and high), with percentage distributions used for comparative analysis. Results: The co-design process resulted in 12 theoretical and practical workshops in infectious diseases and 3 audiovisual products: an animation about malaria, a comic book about cutaneous leishmaniasis, and a puppet show about tuberculosis. The quantitative evaluation applied to the 15 participants revealed substantial improvements, with the proportion that achieved excellent scores in pedagogy increasing from 40% (6/15) to 93% (14/15), in leadership from 13% (2/15) to 27% (4/15). In terms of health knowledge, excellent scores increased from 40% for leishmaniasis, 60% for malaria, and 13% for tuberculosis, reaching 80% for all three diseases. The qualitative evaluation showed positive results in terms of the participants’ perceptions of both the methodology and the co-design process outcomes. Conclusions: The co-design process was driven by 3 key factors: (1) active community participation at every stage; (2) knowledge exchange between multidisciplinary technical expertise and practical local knowledge; and (3) the use of innovative, culturally adapted pedagogical tools tailored to the rural context and population. This co-design process proved to be an effective method for meaningful capacity building among populations experiencing vulnerability in complex settings, and has the potential to contribute significantly to the improvement of infectious disease prevention and control.

Abstract: Conference Title: 2025 IEEE 26th International Conference of Young Professionals in Electron Devices and Materials (EDM) Conference Start Date: 2025 June 27 Conference End Date: 2025 July 1 Conference Location: Altai, Russian Federation Tracking the Long-Term Effects of Biometric Adaptive Learning on Student Habits and Performance. The integration of biometric technologies into educational systems has shown promise in enhancing learning effectiveness and engagement. While short-term studies have demonstrated benefits on immediate academic performance, the long-term impact on student behavior and learning habits remains underexplored. This study investigates the effects of a biometric-based adaptive learning environment over six weeks on students' academic routines, stress management, and knowledge retention. A controlled experiment with 60 undergraduate students divided into three groups—biometric feedback-driven adaptive learning, passive biometric monitoring, and conventional learning—was conducted. Biometric indicators such as heart rate variability, eye-tracking fixation data, and electroencephalogram-derived engagement metrics were continuously monitored. The system adjusted content difficulty and delivery pace based on these indicators. Data on learning behaviors, including time-on-task, late submissions, and participation frequency, were collected, and weekly quizzes assessed knowledge retention. Results revealed that the biometric adaptive group showed significantly higher engagement, reduced stress, improved test performance, a 22% increase in study time, and a 37% decrease in late submissions, indicating a shift toward more self-regulated learning. These findings suggest that prolonged exposure to biometric-adaptive environments can foster sustainable learning habits and long-term academic benefits.

Abstract: Conference Title: 2025 IEEE 26th International Conference of Young Professionals in Electron Devices and Materials (EDM) Conference Start Date: 2025 June 27 Conference End Date: 2025 July 1 Conference Location: Altai, Russian Federation In recent years, biometric technologies have gained significant attention in the field of education, offering new possibilities for personalized learning experiences. This study explores the application of biometric technologies in education management systems to enhance adaptive learning and improve student engagement. The research proposes a model that utilizes biometric data, including facial recognition, eye-tracking, and physiological signals (heart rate, EEG), to assess students' cognitive states in real-time. By analyzing these biometric indicators, the system dynamically adjusts learning materials and teaching strategies to match individual learning needs. The proposed model is implemented using artificial intelligence algorithms to process biometric inputs and personalize the learning environment accordingly. A controlled experiment was conducted with university students to evaluate the system's effectiveness. The results indicate that biometric-driven personalized learning improves knowledge retention and student engagement compared to traditional learning approaches. Additionally, the system demonstrates the potential to identify learners' stress levels and attention spans, enabling more effective educational interventions. This study highlights the potential of biometric-based adaptive learning systems in modern education and suggests future directions for integrating biometric technology into large-scale learning platforms. The findings provide valuable insights for researchers and education policymakers aiming to enhance the efficiency of learning management systems through biometric data integration.

Author: Pantoja-Rojas, Liliana M1    ; Alzate-Monroy, Marco A1; Medina-Garcaa, Vactor H1    ; Moreno-Sandoval, Luis G2    1 Engineering Faculty, Universidad Distrital Francisco José de Caldas, Bogotá, Colombia2 Engineering Faculty, Pontificia Universidad Javeriana, Bogotá, Colombia
Publication info: Pantoja-Rojas, Liliana M; Alzate-Monroy, Marco A; Medina-Garcaa, Vactor H; Moreno-Sandoval, Luis G.
Abstract: This paper presents an agent-based simulation model with cognitive elements, developed to explore strategies for managing complex projects under uncertainty. The model was implemented using NetLogo, which provided a matrix-structured environment where agents—identified as assigners and workers—interact based on factors such as expertise level, intensity of collaboration, frequency of task rotation, and workload balance. The system was simulated over 100 time steps, allowing the identification of behavioral patterns related to organizational learning and performance under varied experimental conditions. Methodologically, the model integrates mechanisms for distributing tasks, rules for agent assignment, adjustable collaboration ranges, and decision-making based on utility functions. Cognitive aspects are addressed through decentralized decision processes and adaptive behaviors that evolve during the simulation. A total of eight configurations were analyzed, varying turnover rates, collaboration distances, and the initial competencies of the agents to assess how these variables influence the accumulation of experience and project effectiveness. The results indicate that when agents build up experience over time, project outcomes improve, following a growth curve with diminishing marginal returns. Conversely, high turnover interferes with knowledge retention and weakens learning processes. Additionally, too much collaboration can overwhelm highly connected agents, thereby decreasing the system’s overall efficiency. Statistical validation was carried out through ANOVA and Spearman’s correlation tests, confirming the consistency and relevance of the observed effects. Overall, the study underscores the importance of organizational continuity and the thoughtful design of collaboration parameters to achieve efficient performance in complex project settings. The proposed model serves as a useful framework for examining how task distribution, talent retention, and interaction patterns can be optimized, and it opens the door to future developments involving more advanced cognitive modeling techniques.

Author: Xu, Kunlun1    ; Liu, Zichen1    ; Zou, Xu2    ; Peng, Yuxin1    ; Zhou, Jiahuan1    1 Wangxuan Institute of Computer Technology, Peking University, Beijing, China2 School of Artificial Intelligence and Automation, Huazhong University of Science and Technology, Wuhan, China
Publication info: Xu, Kunlun; Liu, Zichen; Zou, Xu; Peng, Yuxin; Zhou, Jiahuan.
Abstract: Lifelong person re-identification (LReID) aims to learn from streaming data sources step by step, which suffers from the catastrophic forgetting problem. In this paper, we investigate the exemplar-free LReID setting where no previous exemplar is available during the new step training. Existing exemplar-free LReID methods primarily adopt knowledge distillation to transfer knowledge from an old model to a new one without selection, inevitably introducing erroneous and detrimental information that hinders new knowledge learning. Furthermore, not all critical knowledge can be transferred due to the absence of old data, leading to the permanent loss of undistilled knowledge. To address these limitations, we propose a novel exemplar-free LReID method named Long Short-Term Knowledge Decomposition and Consolidation (LSTKC++). Specifically, an old knowledge rectification mechanism is developed to rectify the old model predictions based on new data annotations, ensuring correct knowledge transfer. Besides, a long-term knowledge consolidation strategy is designed, which first estimates the degree of old knowledge forgetting by leveraging the output difference between the old and new models. Then, a knowledge-guided parameter fusion strategy is developed to balance new and old knowledge, improving long-term knowledge retention. Upon these designs, considering LReID models tend to be biased on the latest seen domains, the fusion weights generated by this process often lead to sub-optimal knowledge balancing. To settle this, we further propose to decompose a single old model into two parts: a long-term old model containing multi-domain knowledge and a short-term model focusing on the latest short-term old knowledge. Then, the incoming new data are explored as an unbiased reference to adjust the old models’ fusion weight to achieve backward optimization. Furthermore, an extended complementary knowledge rectification mechanism is developed to mine and retain the correct knowledge in the decomposed models. Extensive experimental results demonstrate that LSTKC++ significantly outperforms state-of-the-art methods by large margins.

Abstract: Conference Title: 2025 6th International Conference on Inventive Research in Computing Applications (ICIRCA) Conference Start Date: 2025 June 25 Conference End Date: 2025 June 27 Conference Location: Coimbatore, India In the era of information abundance, transforming vast amounts of data into meaningful knowledge remains a critical challenge, especially in domains like medicine, engineering, and education, where visual and multimodal elements play a vital role. Traditional Knowledge Graphs (KGs) excel in organizing structured and textual data but struggle to incorporate multimodal information and implicit relationships, limiting their effectiveness. This paper explores the potential of Multimodal Knowledge Graphs (MMKGs) to address these limitations by integrating text, images, videos, and audio into a unified framework. We investigate how MMKGs enhance knowledge retrieval, comprehension, and interactive learning through advanced techniques, including Natural Language Processing and deep learning. Our findings demonstrate that MMKGs significantly improve knowledge retention and application in specialized fields, offering a foundation for more intuitive and effective domain-specific knowledge ecosystems.

Abstract: Conference Title: 2025 International Conference on Smart Computing, IoT and Machine Learning (SIML) Conference Start Date: 2025 June 3 Conference End Date: 2025 June 4 Conference Location: Surakarta, Indonesia This study presents QuizBattle, a gamified learning application designed to enhance student engagement and comprehension in database education. The development process followed a systematic approach, including iterative design based on user feedback, classroom implementation, and empirical evaluation through surveys and academic assessments. The evaluation results demonstrate that QuizBattle significantly improves various dimensions of student engagement: (1) behavioral engagement increased by 45%, with students reporting greater motivation to attend lectures and participate actively; (2) emotional engagement improved by 38%, reflected in greater satisfaction and enjoyment of the learning environment; (3) cognitive engagement increased by 50%, with students expressing greater interest in the subject and improved knowledge retention; and (4) social engagement was enhanced, with 60% of students indicating that team activities strengthened peer relationships and made their contributions feel valued. These findings suggest that gamified approaches, such as QuizBattle, offer considerable potential for addressing engagement challenges in database education and may be adaptable to other educational contexts.

Abstract: Conference Title: 2025 Eleventh International Conference on eDemocracy & eGovernment (ICEDEG) Conference Start Date: 2025 June 18 Conference End Date: 2025 June 20 Conference Location: Bern, Switzerland This article deals with developing a teaching proposal based on virtual reality that aims to combine theoretical and practical learning in teaching traffic rules. Within the framework of immersive traffic education, a simulator was developed that recreates realistic traffic scenarios and allows users to interact with traffic signals, pedestrians, and environmental factors while receiving detailed feedback on their actions and compliance with current regulations in Ecuador. The project was developed using tools such as Unity to create the graphics engine, Blender for 3D modelling, and the agile SCRUM methodology for iterative development management. In addition, the design and evaluation of the simulator was based on the Design Science methodology, an approach that integrates three key cycles: Relevance, Rigor, and Design. The simulator was evaluated through tests with students and drivers from the Technical University of Manabí, who interacted with the system in controlled scenarios. The results showed high levels of satisfaction, confidence, and perceived effectiveness, with a significant increase in knowledge retention and road safety awareness among users. This immersive learning model stands out as an innovation in the teaching of traffic rules and enables an effective transition from theory to practice in a safe environment.

Abstract: Conference Title: 2025 22nd International Conference on Electrical Engineering/Electronics, Computer, Telecommunications and Information Technology (ECTI-CON) Conference Start Date: 2025 May 20 Conference End Date: 2025 May 23 Conference Location: Bangkok, Thailand Effective knowledge management (KM) is essential for optimizing Scrum-based software development, where iterative processes and informal communication can lead to fragmented knowledge. This study examines current KM practices within a sample organization to identify areas for process improvement. By applying the ISO/IEC 12207 standard, two key processes were prioritized for improvement: (c) Sharing knowledge assets throughout the organization and (d) Managing knowledge, skills, and knowledge assets. To enhance KM within Scrum teams, a structured Knowledge Management Process (KMP) guideline has been established, along with a tailored Knowledge Management System (KMS) designed and implemented for improved knowledge storage, retrieval, and sharing. Nevertheless, successfully implementing the process guideline requires the alignment with the organization's policies and operational needs. This research contributes to the advancement of KM in Scrum-based software development by providing a structured approach that improves knowledge retention, process efficiency, and compliance with industry standards.

Abstract: Conference Title: 2025 Symposium on Maritime Informatics and Robotics (MARIS) Conference Start Date: 2025 June 26 Conference End Date: 2025 June 27 Conference Location: Syros, Greece Aquabots is a development platform for autonomous navigation which was initiated in 2010 by the Rotterdam University of Applied Sciences and system integrator Imtech. In 2014, the first student team successfully crossed the river Nieuwe Maas with their Remotely Operated Vessel (Aquabot) EindMaas. By structuring the project as stacked research, where each team builds upon the work of their predecessors, significant time savings and deeper knowledge development have been achieved. This modular concept, starting from 2017, has enabled various, consecutive student teams to develop individual components of the system architecture. This approach ensured continuity, prevented knowledge loss, and allowed teams to focus on advancing the technology rather than redoing previous work. Over the years, as developments have progressed, it has become increasingly difficult to preserve and extend the knowledge base. To combat the major drawback of various consecutive student teams, a community system will be set up, consisting of teachers, company representatives and students who have contributed to the Aquabots project over the years. This will require active and fruitful cooperation and knowledge sharing, not only from the academic side (students plus teachers), but also from the business sector. We believe that the incubation phase of followup multidisciplinary student teams working on the Aquabots project can be shortened significantly. In this way common resources as well as knowledge can accumulate, academic potential can be explored, and the related business sector will have access to building blocks which can be applied to exploit their business potential. This paper documents best practices and challenges of such a modular learning community.

Author: Dardeer, Faisal M1    ; Areesh, Reem M1; Alnafisi, Aasaiel Ahmed1; Alzain, Ibtesam1    ; Andijani, Basil M1    ; Abudawood, Shahad N1    ; Abdullah, Abeer M1; Ainousa, Abdalrah man M1; Alulaiyan, Mohammed1    1 Department of Pediatric Dentistry, King Abdulaziz University, Jeddah, Saudi Arabia

Abstract: Many dental students lack sufficient knowledge to manage dental trauma. Traditional lectures usually involve one-way communication from the instructor to the students. Game-based learning strategies can increase student engagement, offer hands-on experiences, and promote a deeper interest in learning. Introduction Many dental students lack sufficient knowledge to manage dental trauma. Traditional lectures usually involve one-way communication from the instructor to the students. Game-based learning strategies can increase student engagement, offer hands-on experiences, and promote a deeper interest in learning.To compare the knowledge and satisfaction of dental interns participating in game-based learning versus traditional learning method on traumatic dental management at KAUFD. Objective To compare the knowledge and satisfaction of dental interns participating in game-based learning versus traditional learning method on traumatic dental management at KAUFD.An experimental study conducted at the Faculty of Dentistry at King Abdulaziz University involved a sample size of 88 dental interns. The interns were divided into a game-based learning group (game group) and a traditional lecture group (lecture group). The game group participated in a game-based learning session, engaging in an educational game focused on managing permanent teeth trauma. Meanwhile, the lecture group attended a traditional lecture covering the same topic. Both groups took part in pre- and post-quizzes before and after the sessions and completed a satisfaction survey distributed after the sessions. Methods An experimental study conducted at the Faculty of Dentistry at King Abdulaziz University involved a sample size of 88 dental interns. The interns were divided into a game-based learning group (game group) and a traditional lecture group (lecture group). The game group participated in a game-based learning session, engaging in an educational game focused on managing permanent teeth trauma. Meanwhile, the lecture group attended a traditional lecture covering the same topic. Both groups took part in pre- and post-quizzes before and after the sessions and completed a satisfaction survey distributed after the sessions.Both lecture formats significantly enhanced knowledge retention. Post-intervention scores were comparable between the groups (p = 0.393), The mean post-intervention correct score for the lecture group was 12.72 (SD = 1.33; 95% CI: 12.32-13.13), while the mean score for the game group was 12.62 (SD = 1.56; 95% CI: 12.15-13.09). showing no significant difference in score improvements (p = 0.315). The post-intervention satisfaction survey indicated positive responses in both groups, with no significant differences in satisfaction levels. Results Both lecture formats significantly enhanced knowledge retention. Post-intervention scores were comparable between the groups (p = 0.393), The mean post-intervention correct score for the lecture group was 12.72 (SD = 1.33; 95% CI: 12.32-13.13), while the mean score for the game group was 12.62 (SD = 1.56; 95% CI: 12.15-13.09). showing no significant difference in score improvements (p = 0.315). The post-intervention satisfaction survey indicated positive responses in both groups, with no significant differences in satisfaction levels.The findings indicate that both game-based learning and traditional lectures are equally effective in enhancing knowledge and ensuring high satisfaction among dental interns. Given the similar results, it is recommended to incorporate both approaches in educational settings. Future research should investigate the impact of new content and more complex game designs to understand their potential benefits better. Conclusion The findings indicate that both game-based learning and traditional lectures are equally effective in enhancing knowledge and ensuring high satisfaction among dental interns. Given the similar results, it is recommended to incorporate both approaches in educational settings. Future research should investigate the impact of new content and more complex game designs to understand their potential benefits better.
Supplemental data: The authors report no conflicts of interest in this work.
Title: Comparison Between Game-Based Learning and Traditional Learning Methods in Traumatic Dental Management Among Dental Interns at KAUFD

Abstract: Conference Title: 2025 IEEE 12th International Workshop on Metrology for AeroSpace (MetroAeroSpace) Conference Start Date: 2025 June 18 Conference End Date: 2025 June 20 Conference Location: Naples, Italy The paper presents a proposal for implementing machine learning methods in the diagnosis and troubleshooting process of the M346 aircraft used by the Polish Armed Forces. Due to the complexity and limitations of traditional documentation and procedures, machine learning techniques offer significant potential to enhance accuracy, reduce downtime and improve operational availability. The approach leverages historical fault data and maintenance records to train models that can recommend troubleshooting actions. The integration of artificial intelligence (AI) into aircraft diagnostics addresses key challenges in the current maintenance paradigm and aims to improve fault isolation, maintenance efficiency, and knowledge retention.

Innovative Pedagogy in Engineering Ethic: Validating a Digital Role-Playing Game for Malaysian Pre-university Students
Author: Raja Muhammad Khairuddin Raja Rosli1; Zakaria, Anies Faziehan11 Universiti Kebangsaan Malaysia,Faculty of Engineering and Built Environment,Department of Engineering Education,Selangor,Malaysia
Publication info: Raja Muhammad Khairuddin Raja Rosli; Zakaria, Anies Faziehan.
Abstract: Conference Title: 2025 10th International STEM Education Conference (iSTEM-Ed) Conference Start Date: 2025 July 30 Conference End Date: 2025 Aug. 1 Conference Location: Pattaya, Thailand Engineering ethics education (EEE) in Malaysia remains largely passive, hindering students’ engagement and moral reasoning. To address this gap, a Digital Role-Playing Game-Based Learning (DRPGBL) intervention, Engineering Ethics Enigma (3E), was developed to align with the Malaysian Matriculation Programme curriculum. However, its instructional usability and relevance, required validation. This study reports the iterative testing of 3E through expert review $(\mathrm{n}=12)$ and student pilot testing ($\mathrm{n}=36$). Experts rated content relevance ($M=4.75$) and overall suitability ($M=4.67$) highly, while students echoed these ratings and emphasized learning effectiveness ($M=4.72$). Usability scores improved following targeted refinements. The lowest scores were observed for perceived knowledge retention, highlighting a need for enhanced post-game reinforcement. The results validate 3E as a curriculum-aligned, engaging, and pedagogically sound tool for pre-university ethics education. These findings establish a strong foundation for large-scale quasi-experimental implementation and support the broader integration of DRPGBL in values-driven STEM education.

Abstract: Conference Title: 2025 10th International STEM Education Conference (iSTEM-Ed) Conference Start Date: 2025 July 30 Conference End Date: 2025 Aug. 1 Conference Location: Pattaya, Thailand Traditional biomechanics education often faces challenges engaging students due to its reliance on theoretical concepts and limited interactive feedback. Mobile technology offers a promising solution by enhancing learning experiences through applications designed for human movement analysis. This study examines the effectiveness of OCHY, BeOneSports, and OnForm in improving learning outcomes, student engagement, and STEM integration in biomechanics education. Using a quasi-experimental repeated-measures design, 50 undergraduate students in a biomechanics course were assessed at four stages: Pre-test (Week 1), Post-test 1 (Week 2), Post-test 2 (Week 4), and Post-test 3 (Week 6, two weeks postintervention). Quantitative assessments, surveys, and interviews measured students’ biomechanical analysis skills. A repeatedmeasures ANOVA revealed significant improvements ($\mathbf{p}\lt $ 0.001), with mean scores increasing from $58.4 \%$ (Pre-test) to $68.2 \%$ (Post-test 1), 78.9% (Post-test 2), and 80.1% (Post-test 3). Additionally, $92 \%$ of students reported greater engagement and motivation when using mobile applications compared to traditional methods. Despite these benefits, challenges such as technical constraints, learning curves, and instructor training needs were identified. This study highlights mobile technology’s potential to enhance biomechanics education by integrating STEM principles and promoting active learning. Future research should explore broader student populations, incorporate AR/VR technologies, and examine long-term knowledge retention beyond six weeks to further optimise mobile-based biomechanics education.
